text: Good morning everyone.
Welcome back.
It is April 12th, 2021.
The Council briefing meeting will now come to order.
The time is 9:32 A.M.
Before the clerk call the roll, I'd like to note that Councilmember Sawant reached out to let us know that it is unlikely that you will be able to join us.
He does expect to be in attendance at full council.
Of the clerk please call the roll?
Herbold?
Juarez?
Here.
Herbold?
If you just called me, my volume isn't working.
Thank you.
Councilmember Lewis.
Present.
Morales.
Here.
Mosqueda.
Present.
Pedersen.
Here.
Council President Gonzalez.
Present.
Seven present.
Payment thank you so much.
The minutes of April 5th, 2021 will be adopted.
Hearing no objections, the minutes are now adopted.

The President's report, colleagues, I wanted to start off this morning's Council briefing by acknowledging yesterday afternoon we all heard and read about the horrible news that another incidence of gun violence occurred within our community.
This time in the central district.
At least gun what gunman ran to the corner of an Autozone store and fired East into the parking lot of a strip Mall.
His bullets struck four people, including a 2 year old child, who is as of yesterday, still in critical condition.
Our thoughts of course are with the family and friends of the victims of this incident.
My thanks go out to the first responders, including the Seattle police Department officers were called to this horrific scene, of yet another incident of gun violence within our community.
Spd is asking that anyone with information about the shooting call Homicide detectives to share any information they might have about the shooting.
They can do so by calling 206- 233-5000.
Again, anyone with information about the shooting can share it by calling 206-233-5000.
Our deepest thoughts go to, again all the friends and family of the four survivors at this point.
We hope that everybody has a speedy recovery and we also hope that we see Swifter action from our Federal Government to address the issues related to gun violence in all of our local communities.
Covid-19 vaccines, colleagues, I wanted to remind folks at the top here that of course Covid-19 Vaccinations will start to be available to anyone 16 and older beginning this Thursday, April 15th.
I did send out an Email to each of you and your offices on Friday, late evening.
Making sure that you were aware that the city of Seattle has put together for our own employees a vaccine Website via Sharepoint.
Members of the public can also Preregister for their vaccine at vaccination sites located within the city of Seattle.
It is important for folks to begin now to plan ahead for their vaccine.
You don't have to wait until April 15th if you are a resident of the city of Seattle, or King County, to Preregister.
You can go to our Website at city of Seattle and search for Covid-19 vaccination notification list and get yourself Preregistered for Covid-19 vaccination.
With that being said, colleagues, I'm going to go ahead and have us begin the process of hearing from our team members F█Rom the office O Intergovernmental relations.
They are here with us today to share with us their report out on all of the events that happened last weekend over the weekend since they were left with us.
I'm going to handed over to director Lily Wilson-Codega from the office of Intergovernmental relations to walk you through introductions and the presentation.
Good morning.
Good morning, Lily Wilson- Codega, Oir director.
Robin Koskey, deputy director.
Quinn Majeski, state relations director.
Hannah Smith, government affairs director.
Good morning Council President, Council members.
We are before you today with a state legislative briefing with just over two weeks left in the legislative session.
The House and Senate have released their biannual budget procedures.
Notably both Referencing a 7% capital gains tax.
A high priority for Council.
Both budgets make historic investments in Childcare, human services, support for low income parents, working families.
The immigrant and refugee Committee, and others previously left out of Federal assistance available to residents of our state as well as rental assistance and housing more broadly.
Now, the focus for budget writers will be on reconciling differences between proposals.
As these negotiations continue, we are working with a large collection of other cities that Robin can elaborate on a little more.
She had done a tremendous job of organizing the city coalition.

We will be requesting an additional $400 million in housing investments using the influx of Arpa dollars coming into the state, given a Once- In-A-Lifetime opportunity cities have to house our most vulnerable through rapid acquisition of building, land, hotels, et cetera.
With threats at a historic low point.
Again, Robin will reference this in more detail when she speaks to her portfolio.
We very much appreciate Councilmember Mosqueda joining us for a meeting on Friday to discuss these housing investments.
And our corresponding budget as, we clearly have some work to do there.
We may be reaching out to your offices to engage with specific budget writers are members of the delegation in the coming weeks, giving this is a clinical investment for the state to make.
In our local communities that is certainly a heavy left.
We have passed the final cut out date . The final day of the legislative session is scheduled for Sunday, April 25th.
The remaining two weeks of session will be used to reconcile differences in budgets.
Hopefully with the adoption of the $400 million in additional housing investments across the state.
I will now turn it over to Quinn Majeski, or state relations director.
Thank you, Lily.
In the budget and revenue space, we pretty much covered the state of things.
The House and Senate have all released and passed their versions of the operating capital and transportation budgets.
This past week has largely been devoted to passing legislation before the final opposite House of Lords and cut off that occurred on Sunday.
They are continuing to negotiate with the primary point of difference in negotiations being the allocation of Federal funds.
Guidance has continued to be promulgated by the Federal Government, so we do anticipate particular to the Senate, who allocated fewer Federal funds than their initial proposal.
Both the house and Senate Parsing through and making some additional allocations.
That is the primary point of negotiation.
Outside of that, there is not much to report in the budget and revenue space.
I will go ahead and stop there and pause for any questions.
Colleagues, and the questions? I'm Scrolling to see if I see any.
I don't see any hands.
I think we can continue.
In the education space, all the bills that we were following past last night's cutoff, which is great news.
Several will now head back for reconciliation.
A few exciting votes to share.
The fair starts for kids act, the Senate bill passed the house on Friday.
22 bills dealing effectively in education.
One that requires diversity training and another that requires Antiracism training and assessments in higher education both past . Senate bill 5321, expanding the College-Bound program, past 60- 38.
A bill authorizing bachelor degrees in computer science at community and technical colleges passed 96-2. the President has already signed that one.
A lot of great education bills continuing to move this week.
I'll pause for any questions.
Any questions, colleagues?
I am not seeing any so I think we can continue.
Some big movement this past week in the environmental space.
The Senate passed both the clean fuel standard, the low carbon fuel standard, House bill 1091, and the climate commitment act, also known or commonly referred to as Kapp and invest.
Those past largely on party lines with a few Democrats voting no.
The low carbon fuel standard passed 27-20.
The climate commitment act passed 25 to 24.
The low carbon fuel standard, which originated in the house, now has to go back to concurrence.
The climate commitment act originated in the Senate.
It is not subject to cutoffs.
It is going over to the house for the first time with a hearing coming up on Wednesday this week.
Legislators have often referred to these major environmental bills as being tied to transportation, and in particular, their fates intertwined with a transportation revenue project.
That was made official and memorialized as both bills now for vein provision stipulating they do not go into effect unless the Legislature takes action on transportation revenue.
I will speak to that a bit more once we get to the transportation section.
These major environmental bills, these two certainly, are now very much intertwined with transportation and revenue.
Less connected, but still important, Senate bill 5022, which deals with fiduciary responsibility and standards for recycled content.
That passed the house with strong bipartisan support, which is great to see.

It now has to go back to the Senate floor for concurrence, as does Senate bill 5141, the act which puts in place environmental justice and community engagement standards for a variety of infrastructure projects at the state level.
So, both of those will go back to the Senate for concurrence, as they were amended, but we do anticipate those moving forward and being delivered to the governor's desk.
I'll pause there for any questions on environment.
Colleagues, any questions?
I'm not seeing any hands raised, so I think we can continue.
General government.
Some mixed results here as we move past the final cut off.
The opposite House of origin cut off.
Some bills did make it through.
I should note that even in a long session, there was about a week for bills--a week between the deadlines for bills to move out of committee and the deadline for House of Lords and.
Definitely a compressed Timeline here.
We did see the Juneteenth holiday legislation passed the Senate as well as tax increment financing.
Unfortunately bills that did not make it due to the time crunch and time constraints, the future public meetings legislation.
In a sort of event where there is a need to voluntary comply with staying--staying at home or working from home.
That Unfortunately did not move forward.
Similarly, the state development lands authority, the armory PDA bill, and the Micro enterprise home kitchens legislation all failed to receive a vote prior to the cut off yesterday.
I will pause there for any questions.
I'm not seeing any hands raised.
I think we can keep going.
In the Healthcare space, a lot of more good news.
House bill 1129, that authorizes medical licenses to international medical graduates past 33-15.
1477, which is that national 988 emergency line is Ntib.
It wasn't subject to the cut off but it has an executive session today.
Senate bill 5068, the Postpartum medical bill, passed the house with only one vote against it, which was great news.
5195, reversal medication was amended to reflect that the housing authority establish a program.
That passed the House 89-8 on Friday.
Those are the Healthcare highlights.
I'll pause for questions.
Okay.
I'm looking for any hands.
I don't see any hands up so I think we can continue.
Good morning everyone.

First, I'd just like to start out to say thank you to everyone who signed on to the letter to request significant housing and homelessness funds that Lily talked about in her opening briefing we really appreciate that, and as Lily said, we may need to call on you in the coming days for some additional efforts to get that to the finish line and the final budget.
Lily gave a really good summary of where we are.

I think the only thing I would as is in addition to the local elected leader letter that was sent last Tuesday to legislative leadership, there was also a business letter that went out that had many of the major businesses here in Washington state sign on.
As well as many Chamber and regional business organizations from across the state.

There was also an advocacy Úletter sent by the champion advocacy Fund, which included many housing organizations around the state, and housing development constructions, to show that we really do have a broad base of support for this ask.
We are very hopeful that we will be able to see some additional funds to address housing and homelessness in the final budget this year.
I'd be happy to answer any questions about that.
I think I will just pause for a second.
Councilmember Mosqueda, please.
Good morning, Council President, thank you very much.
Good morning, folks from Oir.
Robin, I think that is helpful for folks to hear a little bit more about where the potential $400 million could come from.

We know it is very late in session and the Federal dollars our new and we are not totally knowing . My understanding is that there is about $700 million in reserves, and part of the Ascus to ask the legislators to dip into part of the reserves that they were holding specifically from the Federal assistance dollars, to then be able to Reallocate this for strategic acquisition and housing and homelessness support.
Is that accurate?
Councilmember Mosqueda, I think that--I am a little Apprehensive about identifying where I believe the money should come from in the budget.
I think that the budget writers have a significant amount of information.

While we do know the House made a lot of indications about where they would like to see Federal money spent, the Senate on the other hand decided to wait, hoping that the Federal government would provide more guidance about how the money could be used specifically.
Over the weekend, I've talked to several legislators and they agree that there is certainly--there is some latitude.
There could be some things that are moved around in order to meet our request.
So, I hope that answers your question.
I do know there is some money for reserves.
There's also the question of whether things could be--when things are spent, whether they are spent in the first year or the second year.
I know they are under the same parameters that we are as a sitter.
We are each receiving a pot of money.
We are only allowed to use half of the money in the first year.
So, there is a chance to defer some expenses to the second year, depending on spending plans for programs et cetera.
Okay, thanks.

I want to acknowledge that this is a pretty late ask, and try to signal our support to the legislators, both for the addition that we are asking a $400 million across the state, but also to recognize that they have, it sounds like on the House side, been pretty specific on trying to identify where the Federal dollars should go.

I appreciate the dollars to have some flexibility in Údeference to legislators to identify where the dollars could come from, and in our efforts to take to make sure that this $400 million is funded, being flexible on our end on where that comes from.
Hopefully we can all continue to send a message that this is also a cost saving measure as we get more folks into housing.
Obviously will cost the state and local housing jurisdictions less.
Our distal notes are not dynamic enough to show those kind of cost savings.
I know that may help with some of the legislative members.
Also to emphasize again that this they Win/Win.
If those are positive things, for business and property owners, as much as it is for healthy economies.
Housing economies, and social services.
Look forward to working with you more, but I know it's late so I wanted to identify if we had been pushing for a certain area for that to come from.
Every dollar is important in this juncture.
I'm also happy about the budgets that came forward and I know that this is going to be good.
We certainly don't want to do one good thing at the cost of another good thing for sure.

I think you brought up a good point that I don't think we had clearly made this morning, Councilmember Mosqueda, one of the reasons we are pushing so hard for this is that we know that there are opportunities in the real estate market right now that will be very unlikely to exist even six months from now.
So, we are trying to capitalize on a moment that we didn't really capitalize on as much as we should have during the last recession.
Trying to learn from the passed and make sure that we can bring as many people inside and increase our stock of affordable housing when we have an opportunity right now.
Okay, so, moving on.
I don't think there are any other questions.
Moving on to the more general housing bill report.
There is a lot of good news that has been happening.
If you would just bear with me for a second, I have the wrong date of my notes up.
[Laughter] House bill 1220, that would require planning for affordable housing and emergency shelter passed the Senate late Saturday evening inside of a Saturday night gift.

The portions of the bill that would have changed zoning for where permanent supportive housing, transitional housing, and emergency shelter was allowed was changed a little bit and now States that a code city may not prohibit housing in either residential or housing hotel zones.
It also shall not prohibit emergency shelters in hotel zones unless an ordinance is adopted that allows for emergency shelter in the majority of zones in that district.
Within one mile of transit.
So, some changes to that bill, but still overall I think a very good bill.
The just cause Eviction bill, House bill 1236.
It also passed.
You will remember last week we had seen that bill get stalled and they were waiting to see what would happen.
There was an agreed-upon amendment for the bill that continues to allow the Probationary period of an initial tendency to allow a no cause Eviction with 60 days notice.
Similar to what was in the original bill.
The provisions are a little bit complicated.

Rather than go into the very minute details here, what I'll agree to do is just provide a written update also in consultation with law, to keep me honest, that I will provide to the Council with all the details later on.
Another part of the bill was that the property owners had asked for, was a delay of implementation of the bill.
For 3 months after the Eviction moratorium.
In order to allow anyone who signed a month-to-month lease to move on to a Probationary six month or more lease under the bill.
These amendments were necessary to pass the bill.
Still a wonderful increase across the state to protect tenants that gives similar protections that tenants have in Seattle to across the state which is really quite historic.
House bill 1277, the bill that would increase the document recording fees by $100 is actually--it was up for executive session on Saturday.
The meeting got kind of waylaid with the Blake decision.
They moved the executive session on that bill to today.
It was merely just a timing issue.
No cause for concern.
That bill may have been exec'd while we were talking here this morning.
I will provide an update there.
Then, Senate bill 5160, that provides tenant protections at the end of the Eviction moratorium, passed the house with an amendment that would prevent the extension of the Eviction moratorium.

There is some work underway to see what might be done about that because there is some concern that in order to get the right to Council provision established, and underway, that they might need a little bit more than a June 30th Eviction deadline.
Expiration.
I'll also keep you posted there.
Still, this is also a historic bill.
We would be the first date in Washington to pass right to counsel statewide.
If this bill does going to law.
In a few weeks.
That's really quite amazing.
Then, finally, the last thing on housing is Senate bill 5287 on MS Te.
That passed the House Saturday morning by a resounding vote of 81-16.
Now it will go to the Senate for concurrence as well.
It provides for a 12 year extension of the program after the initial 12 year tax exemption period.
Therefore, preventing affordable rents from expiring if the developer or the property owner, so chooses to extend for another 12 years.
It establishes a 20 year program for homeownership that will be very helpful to are permanently available homeownership program.
It also survive some tenant protections.
That includes relocation assistance of up to one month.
So, some good news there as well.
I'll pause to see if there are any questions on housing.
Sorry, there was a real lot that happened over the last week in the housing area.
All right.
Any comments or questions, colleagues?
Okay.
I'm not seeing any hands raised.
I think we can keep going.
Terrific.
Moving onto police reform, also quite a bit of activity here.
House bill 1054 that passed the Senate last Tuesday night, that bill bans choke holds, No-Knock warrants, limited use of tear gas, firing on a moving vehicle, and use of military equipment.
That goes on to the house for concurrence.

House bill 1089 requiring Audits of the use of deadly force incidents and Audits to determine if law enforcement agencies are complying with all laws and training requirements passed the Senate as well.
It will now go back to the House--yes, back to the house for concurrence.
Very good news.
House bill 1267, the governor's request legislation that would establish a statewide centralized investigation for use of force.
It passed 27-72.
Similarly, House bill 1310 on use of force passed the Senate on Saturday 27-22.
On the House side, Senate bill 5051, Senator Pedersen's oversight and accountability of peace officers bill, otherwise known as decertification, passed the House by a vote of 54-43.
We'll move back to the Senate for concurrence.
Senate bill 5066, on duty to intervene, passed the House last Wednesday.
Also back to the Senate for concurrence.
Finally, Senator noble's law enforcement data bill passed the House 97-1 last week.
So, quite a bit of historic police reform legislation moving forward as well.
Before I move on to public safety, I'll pause again.
Colleagues, any questions on police reform?
I'm not seeing any hands raised, so we can continue.
In the public safety area, House bill 1320, a very complicated bill that carefully Streamlines all of the protective order statutes passed the Senate Saturday on a vote of 27-20.
Senate bill 5135, unlawfully Summoning a police officer, passed the house on Friday.
Driving with a suspended license, Senate bill 5226 also passed the house on Saturday.
This bill establishes that a failure to pay a traffic infraction will no longer result in a suspension or Revocation of driver's license.
It establishes that an infraction must give the person the option to admit responsibility and attest that you don't have the ability to pay and enter into a payment plan.
To avoid the situation where people are getting into a bad situation with fines building up if they been driving with a suspended license.
Senate bill 5476, which is the Blake decision bill, had kind of an interesting procedural move happen Saturday morning in the ways and Means Committee.
Lawmakers discussed the bill at length, and then decided to move the bill out of committee without recommendation to keep the conversation going.
This is a fairly complicated issue with quite a bit of controversy.
I do think this is going to be one of the issues that we are going to be seeing dealt with at the last day of the session.
I think that is all that I have for my report today.
If there are any questions about public safety I would be happy to answer them.
Any questions, colleagues?
I am not seeing any hands raised, so I think we can go to the next section.
House bill 1072 passed the Senate 28-21 and is headed to the governor's desk.
House bill 1073, paid family leave coverage.
That is now focused on Covid eligibility, passed the Senate 29-20, and will move back for concurrence.
Great news with House bill 1297, the working families tax credit.
It passed 27-2 yesterday.
Adopted amendments require a joint legislative audit review of the program every 10 years.
It ensures that children with individual taxpayer identification numbers qualify to receive the benefit.

There was an amendment changing the benefit structure by household that reduces the amount for childless families and families with one child, but increases the benefit for families with two or more children.
Now, it heads back to the house with those changes.
Senate bill 5214, it passed the House 85-13.
A lot of great movement in the safety net space.
As well.
Thank you.
Go ahead, Quinn.
Thank you, Council President.
Finally, in the transportation space.
In terms of legislation, House bill 1301, providing sound transit with the ability to conduct alternate fair enforcement.
Including Nonmonetary warnings in lieu of citations for the first time.
That passed.
Was also not amended in the Senate which means it does not have to go back for concurrence and will shortly be delivered to the governor's desk.
Good news there.
With the Council Bulletin, I provided a summary and overview of the various transportation proposals and updated proposals that have been released.
I think, I am happy to answer any questions in general.

I think what we can see from this, and I should note that I have done my best to make it an apples to apples comparison between the house and Senate, that is not always how it is--it's difficult to do that.
So, if you're looking at some of the documents that have been put out by the house and Senate you will see that it is sort of portrayed in different ways.
I done my best to make it as close to a Side-By-Side comparison as possible.
I think we can see the House continues to have a much larger proposal, although the revised version has gone down by several billion dollars.
Closer to the Senate.

The House continues to provide more funding for Multimodal than the Senate, although when it comes to specific projects, within the city of Seattle, the Senate provides a bit more funding, including for some specific transit products.
On the revenue side, the House has not put out an updated revenue site proposal.
Since their initial release on January 25th.
However, the Senate has, and they have made some changes.
I think most notably, that includes the new Preemption on local fees.
Food delivery service fees.
There is a Carveout for fees that were adopted prior to the potential passage of this legislation.
The city of Seattle, we could keep our existing fee, how over I know this is still concern.
This is still a Preemption.
It would curtail our opportunities to improve and innovate on the work we Vardy done.
We will be highlighting that.
There is a public hearing happening now.
I apologize because I'm looking at my other screen, monitoring, making sure that I don't get called out and surprised.
Will be speaking to some of those concerns while still highlighting our support for transportation packages.
Wanting to see that Preemption moved out, which would not have an impact on the balance sheet overall.
It Shouldnt be an impediment to them taking action on the investment and infrastructure.
Obviously something we are concerned with.
I will pause there for any questions on transportation.
Colleagues, and the questions on transportation?
I am not seeing any.
Thanks, Quinn for that.
I'm going to hand it back over to Lily for any closing remarks.
I would just say that concludes our briefing for today.
Thank you for your time and engagement.
We will see you next week.
All right.
Colleagues, any other comments or questions before we shift gears?
I am not seeing any, so thanks to each of you.
I know you're Multitasking and trying to do about 1000 things at once.
We appreciate you for doing that and spending sometimes and getting us and members of the viewing public everything.
We will see you next week.
Thank you.
We are going to go ahead and move to the next agenda item.
We will now begin our discussion on agenda item 4, a preview of today's city council actions, Council and regional committees.
I'll call on Councilmembers as established by the roll call.
This week's rotation begins with Councilmember Herbold, followed by Juarez, Lewis, Morales, Mosqueda, Pedersen, and then I will conclude this week's discussion.
I'm going to hand it over to Councilmember Herbold.
Good morning.
You are still on mute.
Okay.
We are going to come back to Councilmember Herbold.
She is having some technology issues that we hope she will be able to resolve.
We will shift gears over to Councilmember Juarez.
You did it again.
I think you're trying to trick me, Council President.
I would never do that.
I would never try to do that.
[Laughter] all right.
There are no items of the public assets and natives Committee on this afternoon's Council agreed to.
The committee met on Tuesday, April 6th two here the remaining appeals . The committee upheld the hearing Examiner's decision, and voted to deny the remaining appeals.
The next step in the process is for Council action on two final pieces of legislation.
Central staff Eric Mcconaughey will provide more information on the next steps.
Thank you for those of you that attended.
I know this has been going on a while now.
A lot to get there.
On this afternoon's agenda is Council bill 120013 which I believe Councilmember Pedersen will be introducing.
That would transfer a plot of land on the Seattle parks Department to the Seattle Department of transportation.
It would expand the Lake City Memorial Triangle.
I will speak more to this community led effort this afternoon.
Thank you Councilmember Pedersen.
Parts, or normal, usual Monday morning update.
The clean city initiative.
The parks Department clean city initiative crew picked up 1000 needles.
63,000 pounds of trash from 62 Encampments.
Two parks received deep cleans.
Bitter Lake and Ocala.
The shower program.
The last two reporting weeks, parks served 637 people in their shower program.
Childcare.
Last week, parks served over 300 children at 17 Childcare sites throughout the city.
The food distribution at Ranier Beach community center, again, food lifeline distributed food boxes to 1400 individuals and families at Ranier Beach.
Regarding district 5, this is a project that has been going on when I was a community member, and certainly as an elected, well before 2015.
Finally, the North pedestrian bike bridge span will be installed over I-95 in May.
May will have a busy week of closures.
The spans will be moved into place and lifted by cranes, and I-5 needs to close safely to complete this work.
Northbound I-5 will close at midnight on Saturday may 8th.
And reopen it for: 30 A.M.
On Sunday, may 9th.
Southbound lanes will close at midnight on Saturday may 15th.
And reopen it for: 30 A.M.
Sunday, may 16th.
This project has been going on for so many years.
It started out with the tiger grant back in 2014.
Two mayors have added an additional $10 Million- $15 million to expand it.
This is a really big thing for us, particularly since light rail is coming and will connect North Seattle college with the Nhl training center and Northgate Mall.
All of our new housing that is coming up.
The whole transit oriented development and housing.
Transit oriented work.
All of that is going to be there so we are excited.
Sound transit announced last week that the Northgate link light rail extension will open to passenger service on Saturday, October 2ND.
I hope you will all join us for a big celebration.
I'll be attending a briefing this week to learn more about the realignment in the next steps.
Last week, I'm sure you all have been talking about this expansively, but it finally has come to a conclusion at least we hope.
The Biden administration canceled the planned sale of the National Archives building at Sandpoint way, located in Councilmember Pedersen's district.
Thank you Councilmember Pedersen for joining with me for asking the city attorney, Pete Holmes to join as plaintiffs with the tribes.
This step REAFFIRMS the Biden's of menstruation, actual Federal law, commitment to tribal consultation.
Congratulations to the tribes, the city of Seattle, and all the plaintiffs.
Second, I attended a Puget sound regional Council transportation policy board meeting.
We approved extension requests to allow projects more time the on their deadlines.
We also voted to recommend approval of supplemental Federal highway administration funding for 2 Seattle projects.
The downtown bike network project, and the Martin Luther King Jr. way projected by Glenn project.
Thank you for those of you that gave us more information.
To all the groups that called in, sent letters, particularly for the bike network project on the Martin Luther King way.
Folks that work with us on the--I'm trying to think of the bite people.
Cascade.
Is a bunch of groups.
Urbanist bite people.
Transportation traces.
All those folks.
Those three things got done and I've done.
I hope Councilmember Herbold's volume is back on.
Thank you, Councilmember Juarez.
You are always prepared to Pivot and I appreciate that.
All right, Councilmember Herbold.
You are up next.
Problems both hearing and projecting.
All the Audio issues you could imagine.
Good morning.
Thank you for the time on the Council briefings agenda.
First off, there are no items from the public safety and human services agenda.
As it relates to my committee meeting on Tuesday, the public safety and human services committee is meeting.
We are going to meet to hear two appointments to the community police Commission.
They are Council initiated appointments.
It will be a short committee meeting tomorrow.
We had planned to hear an update from the human services Department on the new safe and thriving communities division within Hst.
The new division is intended to elevate and consolidate the Department's investments in safety and violence prevention.

It will house the city's work to counter domestic violence, including a team of victim advocates transferred from the Seattle police Department and Hst's existing investments in youth and community safety.
The new division is looking to hire a division director currently.
They are soliciting interested parties for that position.
We hope to hear more about the development of this new division in the public safety and human services Committee on April 27th.
Additionally, we had tentatively scheduled in Committee a discussion and vote on Council bill 1199 81.
That is the carryover bill from last year.
Making a reduction in the police Department's budget.

Coming out of committee, our last committee meeting in March, we had voted to replace the bill, cutting the Department's funding from $5.4 million to about $3 million, transferring funds into Participatory budgeting.
Permitting the police Department to find some of the High-Priority items that they had identified.

Unfortunately, we can't vote on this bill tomorrow because we received direction from the monitoring team that their questions to SPD should be answered as expeditiously as possible, but yet, we have not yet received those answers from SPD yet.
The expectation from the monitoring team is that the Department should respond prior to further actions by the city on the budget of the Seattle police Department.
So, hopefully we will be able to bring those forward again on April 27th.
I'd like to say just a few words about the gun tragedy over the weekend.
As we know, gun violence is on the rise throughout the nation.
It's an all too tragic reality everywhere.
When it's in our own city as well, it's particularly painful.
I hope for the recovery of the victims and my heart goes out to their families and loved ones.
Each year, nearly 40,000 Americans died by suicide, Homicide, or accidents with firearms.
In King County alone, more people are killed by firearms than by car crashes with an annual financial cost of nearly $200 million.
President Biden's recent executive order to address in a small way what is an enormous problem, is welcome.
In the United States we have 121 guns per 100 people.

In addition to encouraging States to Mosler Washington state' own on program barring known dangerous people from owning guns and mandating that so-called ghost guns have serial numbers, the executive order includes $5 billion for community violence intervention efforts.
Again, my hopes for healing to the family and loved ones of the victims from this tragic shooting, as well as the broader community.
I want to also speak to the Seattle transit about SPD Off- duty work.
That was published yesterday.
Just want to provide a little bit of information about my own inquiries about this.
In September, I wrote to chief Diaz to inquire about the status of former Mayor Burgess' executive order of September 27th--2017.
This executive order ordered the Seattle police Department to establish an internal office, directed and staffed by civilians, to regulate and manage the off-duty employment of its employees.
The task force of SPD and executive branch officials was formed to work on this project and the requirements were laid out by the off-duty Workgroup.
It included reporting on Off- duty hours reporting worked by individuals.
The Council had some follow-up questions about the status of the executive order.
We received follow-up information in 2018. that's where we learned about the overtime work group and the report said that this work would be ongoing.
In my September letter of 2020, I asked what the status of the project was.
The status is two fold.
It is both regarding the Detracting of off-duty hours.
As well as changes in policy limiting off-duty work.

As it relates specifically to the tracking, the response received from the chief was that the work schedule and Timekeeping project system could support the work . meaning supporting the work of tracking the hours.
The work scheduled Timekeeping project is a technological project that the police Department is undertaking right now.
The chief goes on to say that it is not scoped to do so.
He said there would need to be substantial policy and operational work on how Off- duty time would be managed beyond what was put in place.
Following the executive order of Mayor Burgess.
It goes on to say that the work schedule and Timekeeping system was scoped to ensure it could support the work, but the project is not currently incorporating it.

Instead, they are working on logging off-duty work in the computer aided dispatch system and do not have sufficient resources without the work schedule and Timekeeping system to link up off-duty hours reported in the CAD to aggregate them for current total thresholds.
The response goes on to say that officers must also currently logged their off-duty work in the blue teams system, which feeds an internal dashboard that is reviewed monthly.
Finally, so that's just all about the tracking piece.

As a relates specifically to limiting the number of off-duty hours officers can do and regulating that area, the chief goes on to say, in early 2019 it was determined that the current contract places limits on the changes that can be made to the off-duty process.
Any additional changes in the administration of off-duty work must be addressed in future labor negotiations.
He closes saying it is my understanding that there were real concerns from the city about impact on retirement packages.
If any off-duty pay hours were officially Contracted/Tracked by the city.
Moving on to the updates from the human services Department.

Monday through Saturday during business hours and interpretation is available.

For public health . We are very close to putting the worst of the pandemic behind us, but of course we are not in the clear yet.
The moment the virus is spreading quickly then we can vaccinate.

Everyone ages 16 and older in Washington state will become vaccine eligible starting this week.
On April 15th.

Even if you won't be eligible.

Again, as a reminder, the vaccination sites that the city operates are at West Seattle lumen field, North Seattle college, and Rainier Beach.
Where the numbers of vaccines available to us here in King County are on the rise, but it is still a problem.
Please understand that you will take some time and patience for everyone to get Vaccinated.
In the meantime, continue to limit your activities with Unvaccinated people.
Outside of your home.
Avoid those crowded indoor spaces . make sure that when you are inside, that you are in a location with ventilation that includes sometimes opening the doors and your windows to keep that air moving.
Stay home and get tested if you have Covid symptoms or were exposed to somebody who tested positive.

I continue to share the concern of 20 environmental and community organizations about the decision transportation officials made a few years ago to narrow Brooklyn Avenue.
Which Unfortunately Impedes access for more buses.
Ideally Brooklyn Avenue would have remained wide enough to accommodate most buses, and provide seamless transfers from bus to light rail.

As all the light rail stations open, our Seattle Department of Transportation will need to stay tightly coordinated with King County Metro to adjust bus routes based on rider feedback from the thousands who will be transferring from bus to light rail.
Overall, the opening of the stations just six months away, is great news.
More good news, there's another capital project benefiting district 4, especially the nearly 1000 low income residents who call Magness park on.
Last week, Sdot confirmed the construction of the pedestrian safety improvements will begin later this month, including Crosswalks and sidewalks along Sandpoint way adjacent to our regional park.
I believe this highlights one of the benefits of our hybrid counselor election system that includes representation by districts.
Due to our knowledge of the neighborhood on the ground, we are able to lift up the benefits to the low income residents there and present this pedestrian safety project from being stalled.
I want to thank my colleagues for joining me to enable this project to move forward quickly.
That concludes my report.
